full_text:
1
IN THE COURT OF THE SESSIONS JUDGE,
THIRUVANANTHAPURAM
PRESENT : SMT. NAZEERA.S, SESSIONS JUDGE
On Tuesday, 4" day of March 2025/13" day of Phalguna, 1946.
Criminal M.C.No. 652/2025

Crime No 47/2025 of Pallickal Police Station, Pending before the

Judicial First Class Magistrate Court -II Attingal

Petitioner/Accused _:-

Babu aged 61 years S/o. Bhargavan

BB Bhvan Near Pakalkuri LPS

Pallickal Village Thiruvananthapuram

By Advocate:- ZareenaR
Counter Petitioner :-

Sub Inspector of Police
Pallickal Police Station
By Public Prosecutor Dr. T. Geenakumari
This Criminal M.C. is coming on for hearing on 03.03.2025 and the court
on 04.03.2025 passed the following ::
ORDER

This is an application filed by the sole accused in the above crime under
Section 483 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, seeking regular bail.

2. The petitioner/accused is alleged to have committed the offences
punishable under Sections 296(b), 118(1), 126(2), 124(1) and 109(1) of the
Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita.

3. The prosecution allegation in brief is as follows:- The accused is
the husband of the defacto complainant. On 30.01.2023, the accused attempted

2

to commit murder of the defacto complainant and her daughter by pouring
petrol over their body and by setting them fire. A case was registered in this
regard as Crime No. 105/2023 of Pallickal Police Station, registered for the
offences punishable u/ss. 294(b), 506, 511 of 436 and 308 of Indian Penal
Code. Due to this animosity, on 10.01.2025 at about 7 p.m., the accused
entered into the hall room of the house of the victim, situated in Pallickal
Village and uttered abusive words against her, caught hold of her hair and
forcefully poured acid into her mouth. As a result, the acid fell on the face,
lips, nose and back of the victim, causing grievous burn injuries.

4. Reportedly, the petitioner/ accused was arrested on 11.01.2025 and
he is in custody since then.

5. Notice in this bail application is issued to the Public Prosecutor. The
Investigating Officer filed report opposing the bail application.

6. Heard. Perused the records.

7. The only point to be considered is, whether regular bail can be
granted to the petitioner/ accused.

8. The Point:- The petitioner/accused is the husband of the defacto
complainant. It is alleged that, the petiitoner/accused had attempted to cause
death of his wife by pouring acid. The motive for the alleged incident is the
animosity that arose when the defacto complainant filed a complaint before the
police when the accused attempted to kill her and her daughter.

3

9. According to the petitioner, he is innocent of the allegations
levelled against him. It is submitted by the petitioner that, the injuries are simple
in nature and it only attracts the offences punishable u/ss. 118(1) and 124(2) of
Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, and Section 109(1) of Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita is not
attracted in this case.

10. The magnitude of the offence alleged is grave. Allegedly, the
petitioner/accused had poured acid into the mouth of his wife/defacto
complainant. Reportedly, the defacto complainant/victim had sustained burn
injuries in the incident. The certificate of examination by the Medical Officer
shows that burns are seen on the right upper chest and axilla. It is seen that the
dying declaration of the victim was also recorded from Medical College
Hospital, Thiruvananthapuram. So the prosecution has made out the prima
facie case against the petitioner and the involvement of the petitioner / accused
in the alleged offence. The learned Public Prosecutor strongly opposed the bail
application stating that the petitioner is having great animosity against the
defacto complainant and he is following her to do away her, and so releasing
the petitioner on bail would be a threat to the defacto complainant. In the
dying declaration appended along with the report, it is seen that the victim had
given statement to that effect. It is stated in the report that the petitioner is
involved in five other crimes. The investigation in this case is progressing.
The petitioner / accused is in judicial custody only for a period of 52 days. If

4
the petitioner/ accused is released on bail at this stage, he is likely to influence
or intimidate the victim and the other witnesses and tamper with the evidence.
The chance of absconding also cannot be ruled out. So, the investigation will
be adversely affected. Considering all the afore facts, including the gravity of
the offence, this court is not inclined to release the petitioner on bail at this
stage.
In the result, this petition is dismissed.
(Dictated to the Confidential Assistant, transcribed and typed by him, corrected
and pronounced by me in Open Court on this the 4" day of March 2025)
NAZEERA S.
SESSIONS JUDGE
